results.title: The Reflecting pool: collected work 1977-80
results.creator_credit: Artists' Television Workshop at WXXI/TV, Rochester, TV Lab at WNET/Thirteen, Bruce Hutter, Mike Ballenger, Carol Brandenburg, Carvin Eison and Bill Viola
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Viola describes The Reflecting Pool as ‘a collection of five independent works which, taken as a whole, describe the stages of a personal journey using images of transition — from day to night, motion to stillness, time to timelessness, etc. Each work explores specific video techniques and technologies, in combination with the spatial potentials of stereo sound.’ In the title work, all movement and change in an otherwise still scene is confined to the reflections on the surface of a pool in the woods. Suspended in time, a man hovers in a frozen, midair leap over the water, as subtle techniques of still-framing and multiple keying join disparate layers of time into a single coherent image. Viola writes that ‘the piece concerns the emergence of the individual into the natural world — a kind of baptism.’ He describes Moonblood as an expression of the feminine principle, a work in three parts relating to a personal concept of woman and mother. Day and night converge within the silhouette of a woman at a window — a rushing waterfall in winter, and the serene interplay of changing dawn light unfolds within a glass of water at dawn in the desert.’ Silent Life’ records the first hours and days of life through a series of portraits of newborn babies in a hospital nursery. The alienating hospital environment, and the vulnerability of the babies’ pre-lingual gestures and expressions, suggests a primal linking of birth and death. Ancient of Days is a remarkable series ofcanons and fugues for video’ that comprises Viola’s most sophisticated structural and metaphorical explorations of time. Mathematical notations of precise time-code editing were applied to construct illustrations of temporal symmetry, duality and transposition — time-based equivalents of musical compositional principles such as counterpoint and serialism. Astonishing temporal interventions — a 180-degree pan gazing downward on a New York City street that progresses from day to night, an image of Mount Rainier in which the foreground and background unfold in different time planes — unfold as symbolic transformations of natural and urban landscapes. The title of Vegetable Memory derives from the writings of Jalaludin Rumi, 13th-century Persian poet. Evolving as what he terms a ‘kind of temporal magnifying glass,’ the tape explores the perceptual phenomenon of repetitive, cyclic viewing. A loop of images recorded at the Tsukiji fish market in Tokyo is extended in progressively slower cycles, changing the form, feeling and ultimately the meaning of the original images as they move further into the subjective and pictorial.

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
Titled The Stars Were. This film shows closeups of the children who starred in “Walking to School” and “The Bear”.

The film then moves on to show a tractor dragging flames to set fire to a dry paddock. We see various farm scenery including sheep, burning off, horse riding and a tractor ploughing a field.

The film then shows a narrative short story titled “The Wish Wizard” which could be an Eaglehawk Primary school production. This film shows school children discovering a book which contains a map to “The Olde Wishing Well”. They gather together and conjure up a wizard using a magic spell. We see good close ups of children’s faces as they interact with the wizard.

We then see a school boy walking and running down a country road where he discovers animal tracks in the dirt and encounters a woman wearing a red coat carrying apples in a basket.

This film shows good examples of school fashion, children’s faces and farming practices.

Selected highlights (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:49:00 - Title card Story ‘The Bear’
00:01:05:00 - Burning off with tractor
00:02:56:00 - Title card ‘the wish wizard’

results.title: [Kirsty Sword Gusmao Film Collection: Reel 1]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a slice of life from a working dairy farm in central Gippsland, Victoria.

We see cows being milked, the milk cans being loaded onto trucks and in to the trays of utility cars. The milk is transported by road to the Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Company.

There are scenes of hay bales being driven around the paddocks in the back of a ute. The hay is divided in to sections and fed to the cattle. We see de-horned Jersey and Friesian cows and bulls eating the hay and children riding a WX 572 tractor.

There is footage of a newly born calf being licked clean by its mother and we see the calf’s first attempt to stand and take its first steps.

The film also shows a family visit to the Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point.

Selected sequence list (timecodes from Access Overscan)
00:00:54:00 The Maffra Co-operative Milk Products Co LTD sign
00:02:12:00 Title card ‘A Calf is Born’
00:03:55:00 Dad and kids riding a tractor
00:04:00:00 Title card ‘Wattle Time’
00:04:38:00 Glenmaggie Dam Enlargement Project Observation Point

results.title: [Cinesound Review: Royal Tour Concludes]
results.creator_credit: Peter Bell, William M. Carty and Cinesound
results.brief_description:
This film is a Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The newsreel shows the final leg of the 1970 Royal Tour with Queen Elizabeth II, Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh and Princess Anne, for the bicentenary celebrations of the arrival of Captain James Cook in Australia in 1770.

The film shows the royal family arriving in Brisbane, Queensland, on the Royal Yacht Britannia, where they are greeted by crowds of people in hundreds of boats on the river. It shows the family attending various events, including a welcome at Parliament House, theatre shows and a children’s parade at Lang Park, or Brisbane Stadium.

Princess Anne visits a sheep station at Cunnamulla, Queensland, while Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip visit the mines at Mount Isa, Queensland.

The film shows bicentenary celebrations in Cooktown, Queensland, and Botany Bay, New South Wales. These celebrations include a speech by the Queen and re-enactments of Captain James Cook’s arrival in Australia in 1770, with interactions with Aboriginal Australian people.

The film continues with fireworks over Sydney Harbour; an ANZAC Day march in Canberra, Australian Capital Territory; Prince Philip playing polo with a local team; and the opening of the international terminal at Sydney Airport, from which the royal family departs.

results.title: [Cinesound Review 1950-1965]
results.brief_description:
This film contains excerpts from Cinesound Review, a news broadcast that covered significant social, cultural and political events in Australia. The film features a number of different clips from newsreels between 1950 and 1965.

The first section, titled ‘1950 Melbourne Cup’, shows the horse race at Flemington Racecourse, photographed by Ron Horner. The film includes close-ups of people in the crowd, and commentary of the race as Comic Court wins. This is followed by a section titled ‘Scone Rodeo: Bronchos (sic) on the Bust’, featuring footage of a horse rodeo in Scone, New South Wales.

The third section, titled ‘Fur Flies: Battling Budgerigar K.O.’s Cat’ features a playfight between two pets, a ginger cat and a budgerigar. In the fourth section we see ANZAC Day parades in Melbourne and Sydney, preluded by the title ‘ANZAC: Nation’s Homage’.

The fifth section is titled ‘Skiing: Day and Night Fun at Mt. Buller’, with commentary by David Low. It features children learning how to ski and social activities in the resorts, including bands and dancing. This is followed by an excerpt called ‘Clark Well Ahead’, showing the motorcar race at the 1965 British Grand Prix, won by Jim Clark.

The film ends with a cartoon called ‘Local Boy Makes Good: A Story with a Moral’ and three feature film trailers: ‘The Counterfeit Traitor’ (1962), ‘Pollyanna’ (1960) and ‘Mein Kampf’ (1960).

results.title: Woman in a house
results.brief_description: One of Sue Ford’s earliest films, “Woman in a house” is a feminist critique of domestic female roles. In this short film, a young woman in a suburban house escapes the confinement of her life through surreal dream sequences created with experimental montage techniques. Made in 1972, the film was shown at screenings run by the Melbourne Filmmaker’s Co-op and was one of the most popular films available to rent from the feminist film collective Reel Women, of which Ford was a founding member, in the late 1970s and early 1980s.
